conclusion: Principles of shadow formation and effects of light source position on shadows.
The light source is currently positioned to the left of the objects, casting shadows to the right.
Shadows are formed on the opposite side of the light source.
The length and direction of the shadow depend on the angle of the light source relative to the object.
When the light source moves to the back right, it will be positioned behind and to the right of the objects.
The shadows will shift to the left and forward because the light source is now behind and to the right.
The shadows will generally become longer as the light source moves further away from the objects in a horizontal plane.
The angle of the light source will also affect the elongation of the shadows.
Shadow A (Apple) moves to the left and forward and becomes longer.
Shadow B (Paper) moves to the left and forward and becomes longer.
Shadow C (Glass) moves to the left and forward and becomes longer.
Shadow D (Drumstick) moves to the left and forward and becomes longer.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will shift to the left and forward and become longer.
